Chapter 7, Part 3: Distinguishing the Noble Ones, has already explained the differences in the arising of the two paths of seeing and cultivation. One should rely on the distinctions in the stages of these paths to establish the various noble beings.
As for establishing the distinctions among the noble ones based on the fifteen moments of mind in the path of seeing, the verse says:
They are called followers of faith and followers of the dharma, distinguished by dull and sharp faculties,
Fully possessing afflictions to be eliminated, up to five, heading towards the first fruit,
Eliminating the next three, heading towards the second, free from the eight stages, heading towards the third.
The treatise says:

In the stage of the path of seeing, there are two kinds of noble ones: followers of faith and followers of the dharma. The two names are established based on the distinctions of dull and sharp faculties.
Those of dull faculties are called followers of faith, because they cultivated the preparations based on the power of faith and respect from before.
Those of sharp faculties are called followers of the dharma, because they cultivated the preparations based on delighting in contemplation from before.

The various kinds of sentient beings are distinguished by their spiritual genes, which are established naturally from beginningless time. Some are not inclined to observe the various activities of the world, and some are inclined to observe them. Those who are able to change their inclinations are called the two kinds of noble ones. Because of the difference in the complete or incomplete abandonment of the passions that are objects to be eliminated by the path of cultivation, they are established as the three kinds of candidates for the fruit.

That is, if the two kinds of noble ones have not previously eliminated the passions that are objects to be eliminated by the path of cultivation by means of the worldly path, they are called those who are bound by all the bonds.

Or, if they have previously eliminated one to five categories of the passions of the realm of desire, they are called candidates for the first fruit when they reach this stage, because they are approaching the first fruit.
The first fruit is called the fruit of stream-enterer, because it is necessarily the first of all the fruits of Å›ramaá¹‡as.

If they have previously eliminated six, seven, or eight categories of the passions of the realm of desire, they are called candidates for the second fruit when they reach this stage, because they are approaching the second fruit.
The second fruit is called the fruit of once-returner, because it is the second of the fruits of the Å›ramaá¹‡a.

If one has previously already been free from the nine grades of passion of the desire realm, or has previously already eliminated the first trance, up to being completely free from the sphere of nothingness, at this stage one is called the third fruit-stage, because one is heading for the third fruit.
The third fruit is called the fruit of non-returner. The number is explained as before.
Thus, the followers of faith and followers of the dharma, due to the differences in eliminating delusions while still bound by all, are separately established as seventy-three types.
That is to say, from being bound by all in the desire realm as the first, up to eliminating the ninth grade as the tenth.
In this way, up to the sphere of nothingness, each ground has nine, making seventy-three.
The subsequent bound by all is the previous free from nine, therefore the latter seven grounds have no separate bound by all.
Next, based on the time of the path of cultivation and the knowledge of the classes of the path, the establishment of the differences of the various sages is as follows. A verse says:
Up to the sixteenth thought, following the three directions and abiding in the fruits,
Are called faith-understanding and view-attainment, also due to the distinctions of dull and sharp.
The Treatise says:

Those who previously followed faith and those who previously followed the teachings, when they reach the sixteenth mind of the path of insight into the four truths, are called abiders in the fruit and are no longer called candidates. They abide in the three fruits according to the previous three candidates.

That is, those who were previously candidates for the fruit of stream-enterer now abide in the fruit of stream-enterer; those who were previously candidates for the fruit of once-returner now abide in the fruit of once-returner; those who were previously candidates for the fruit of non-returner now abide in the fruit of non-returner.

The fruit of arhatship is definitely not attained for the first time, because ordinary beings are not able to be free from the peak of existence, and the path of insight is not able to eliminate the proclivities to be eliminated by cultivation.

When one reaches the stage of abiding in the fruit, one abandons the two names of candidate and obtains the two names of one who attains through faith and one who attains through views. This is also due to the difference of dullness and sharpness of faculties.
Those of dull faculties, who were previously called those who follow faith, are now called those who attain through faith, because the power of faith is superior and resolve is manifested.

Those of sharp faculties, who were previously called those who follow the teachings, are now called those who attain through views, because the power of wisdom is superior and right views are manifested.

Why is it that when one has previously eliminated one to five degrees of the passions that are to be eliminated by cultivation in the realm of desire, or seven or eight degrees, or one degree of the first trance state, and so on, up to the ninth degree of the ninth trance state, and at the time of the sixteenth mind of the path of insight into the truths, one is only called a â€œstream-winner,â€ â€œonce-returner,â€ or â€œnon-returner,â€ and not a â€œonce-returner,â€ â€œnon-returner,â€ or â€œarhatâ€?
A verse says:
In the state of attaining the fruit, one has not yet attained the path of the superior fruit.
Therefore, before the superior path is produced, one is called a dweller in the fruit and not a candidate for the fruit.
The treatise says:

The eight saints are established on the basis of the attainment of the path of the saints. Therefore, in the state of first attaining the fruit, one has not yet attained the path of the superior fruit. Because the mind that attains the fruit is not the antidote to the passions that are to be eliminated by the path of the superior fruit.
It is definitely not the case that when the antidote to those passions is present, one attains the path that is the antidote to them.

Also, when one attains the fruit, the acquisition of the separation from the bonds that are eliminated by the path of the superior fruit does not arise, because the receptivity to the knowledge of the doctrine in regard to the path cannot eliminate the acquisition of those bonds.

If the power of the path can sever the acquisition of those bonds, and this path induces the arising of the acquisition of separation from those bonds, then it can be said that this path can realize the cessation of those bonds. Because when one attains a prior fruit, one has not yet attained the path of a superior fruit.

Even though one who abides in a fruit has already severed the first category of the passions to be eliminated by cultivation, etc., he is only said to abide in a fruit and not to be a candidate for the subsequent fruit until he generates the path of a superior fruit.
At what time does one acquire the pure acquisition of separation from the passions to be eliminated by cultivation that were previously severed?
One acquires them when the path of a superior fruit is present.

After one has severed all the passions to be eliminated by cultivation and has entered the state of being free from passions, does one necessarily generate the path of a superior fruit in this life after having attained a prior fruit?
Reason demands that this must be so.
Because the ÅšÄstra says:

Holy ones born in the fourth trance state and above necessarily accomplish the pure faculty of pleasure, because they must delight in it since its obstacle has already been eliminated, and because the path that eliminates its obstacle is easy to manifest.

Thus, in the sixteen moments of the path of seeing, those who have already completely or partially abandoned the desires of the realm of desire are established as the various holy beings. Now, in terms of the afflictions of the realm of form and the formless realm, we will discuss the gradual arising of the counteracting paths and their stages of distinction.
A verse says:
In each stage, there are nine faults and virtues, each divided into three levels: lower, middle, and upper.
The treatise says:
Faults refer to faults, which are the obstacles to be eliminated.
Virtues refer to virtues, which are the counteracting paths.

As explained above, the afflictions to be eliminated through cultivation are divided into nine grades. The four formless concentrations and the four formless absorptions should be understood in the same way, because birth and death are subsumed in the nine stages.

Just as the obstacles to be eliminated are divided into nine grades in each stage, the counteracting paths, the uninterrupted paths and the liberated paths, are also divided into nine grades in the same way.
How are the faults and virtues each divided into nine grades?

That is, the fundamental stage has three grades, superior, medium, and inferior, and each of these is divided into three, superior, medium, and inferior. Consequently, errors and virtues are divided into nine grades. That is, inferior-inferior, inferior-medium, inferior-superior, medium-inferior, medium-medium, medium-superior, superior-inferior, superior-medium, and superior-superior.

You must understand that the power of the path of the inferior-superior grade can eliminate the obstacle of the superior-superior grade, and so on, up to the power of the path of the superior-superior grade that can eliminate the obstacle of the inferior-inferior grade. Because the superior-superior grade, etc., of the virtues that are antidotes do not yet exist at the beginning, and because at the time when these virtues exist, the errors of the superior-superior grade, etc., no longer exist.
You must understand that in this context, even though knowledge is superior to delusion, it is called the inferior grade of the path because it is not yet vigorous.
Even though the delusion in a continuum is extremely difficult to eliminate because it is subtle and follows along, the obstacle is called the inferior grade.
In accordance with this principle, you should establish a simile, just as in the process of washing clothes, coarse stains are removed first, and then gradually finer stains are removed.
Also, it is like the case where coarse darkness is extinguished by a small light, but subtle darkness is extinguished only by a great light.
The principle of the contrast between faults and virtues is also like this.
For this reason, it can be said that the good overcomes the bad, because the path of elimination arises for a moment and uproots the roots of all passions that have existed since beginningless time.
Having distinguished the nine grades of faults and virtues, next we will establish the distinctions among the holy ones based on them.

First, those in the path of cultivation who have not yet eliminated any of the passions are generally called those liberated by faith and those who have attained insight, but there are many distinctions based on their stages. We will first establish those who have not yet eliminated any of the passions.
A verse says:
Those who have not yet eliminated the losses of the passions eliminated in the path of cultivation are called those who attain the fruit of stream-entry and return to the world up to seven times.
The commentary says:

Those who have attained the fruit of stream-entry have not yet eliminated any of the losses of the passions eliminated in the path of cultivation in any of the stages. They are called those who attain the fruit of stream-entry and return to the world up to seven times.
The word seven times indicates seven comings and goings in birth. It means that they are born seven times among humans and gods.
The word â€œat mostâ€ is used to show that the maximum number of rebirths is seven, not that all stream-enterers have exactly seven rebirths.
Therefore a scripture says:
At most they have seven rebirths.
This means that the maximum number of rebirths is seven, and this is not different from the meaning of the scripture.
All pure paths are generally called a stream, because they are the cause that leads to nirvÄá¹‡a.
The word â€œpreâ€ in the term â€œpre-streamâ€ shows that one first attains this stream, and therefore it is called the â€œpre-stream.â€
What does the term â€œpre-streamâ€ mean?
If one who first attains the path is called a pre-stream entrant, then the term pre-stream entrant should refer to the eighth.

If one who first attains the fruit is called a pre-stream entrant, then those who are free from the passions of the two lower stages and those who are completely free from the passions should be called pre-stream entrants when they reach the path of insight into the truths.
The term pre-stream entrant refers to one who first attains the fruit.

However, those who are free from the passions of the two lower stages and those who are completely free from the passions are not called pre-stream entrants when they reach the path of insight into the truths, because they are established as that fruit on the basis of the elimination of the passions that are eliminated in the path of cultivation.
The pre-stream entrant is necessarily one who has attained the fruit by means of the universal path, because the first fruit that is attained is used to establish the name.
The once-returner and nonreturner are not definitely attained for the first time, because only this fruit is necessarily attained for the first time.
Why is this name not applied to the eighth?

Because he has not yet fully obtained the path of the approacher to the fruit of once-returner, because he has not yet fully obtained the pure paths of insight and cultivation, and because he has not yet fully attained the stream of insight.

The eight forbearances and eight knowledges are called the stream of insight. At the time of the knowledge of the state of an arhat, all are fully attained. Therefore the eighth is not called a stream-enterer. For this reason, the stream-enterer is only the first fruit.
After this, he is reborn in the heavens and human realm, each seven times.
It should be said that he is reborn fourteen times. Why is it said that he is reborn a maximum of seven times?
This criticism is not valid, because the number seven is equal to the seven-leaved tree and the seven good factors.

By the power of the holy path, he does not exceed seven existences. Although the holy path is present in the interim, the power of the remaining actions holds him back and he does not realize nirvÄá¹‡a. Only in dependence on the Buddha appearing in the world is there a separate morality.

If they do not encounter the Buddha's teachings, they will attain the fruit of arhatship at home. Having attained the fruit, they will definitely not remain at home, and the demeanor of a bhiká¹£u will naturally be accomplished.
Although they may not encounter the teachings spoken by the previous Buddha, they will give rise to extreme disgust towards the rest of their lives, and before long they will enter complete nirvana.
If one attains the fruit of stream-entry in the human realm, one will be reborn in the human realm seven times at most. This should be understood to apply to the heavenly realm as well.
Non-noble ones may also have up to seven rebirths, and through the maturation of their continuity attain nirvana. However, this is not definite, and therefore it is not mentioned.
Having explained that one who has not yet eliminated any of the cultivated afflictions is called a stream-enterer who will be reborn at most seven times,
we should now discuss the various sages who have eliminated [afflictions]. First, we should establish the approach and fruit of the once-returner.
A verse says:
Having eliminated three or four categories of desire realm [afflictions], one is a family-to-family [returner] with three or two rebirths.
Having eliminated up to five categories, one is a candidate for the second fruit. Having eliminated six categories, one attains the fruit of once-returning.
The treatise says:

If a stream-enterer, on the basis of these three conditions, eliminates three or four of the classes of the passions that are to be eliminated during the path of cultivation, he is called a family-to-family.

The first condition is that of eliminating passions, because he has eliminated three or four of the classes of passions to be eliminated during the path of cultivation in the realm of desire. That is, he either eliminated them in the state of ordinary person prior to the path of insight, or he eliminates them in the state of the path of cultivation as a stream-enterer.

The second condition is that of perfecting the faculties, because he has perfected the pure faculties that are able to eliminate those passions. That is, he has perfected the three or four classes of pure faculties that are able to eliminate the three or four classes of passions.

The third condition is that of being reborn, because he will be reborn in the realm of desire three or two more times. That is, having eliminated three classes of passions, he will be reborn three more times; having eliminated four classes of passions, he will be reborn two more times.

These three or two rebirths are due to the actions that were created and increased in the state of ordinary person that will result in three or two rebirths. It is not the case that the saints, while in the state of the path of insight, are able to create anew actions that will result in a later existence, because they turn their backs on saá¹ƒsÄra and face nirvÄá¹‡a. Consequently, a scripture says, Saints experience the results of previous actions but do not create new actions.
If any one of the three conditions is lacking, or if two or all are lacking, one is not called a family-to-family.
Why is it called a root?
The verse does not say that after the fruit of stream-entry, one progresses in cutting off afflictions and accomplishing the pure roots that can counteract them.
Because it is already established by implication, it is not fully explained.
If that is so, then one should not say three or two births, because the meaning of cutting off the fourth or third category is already established.

That is to say, if one has already progressed in cutting off the fourth or third category of afflictions, it is certain that there are three or two remaining births, so the characteristics of the family-to-family are not complete. Then, one should add the word etc. to the verse in order to fully include the three characteristics of the family-to-family, or one should not say three or two births.
However, the verse says three or two births because there is progress, and one may have fewer or no births in what is received, or more than that.
It should be known that there are generally two kinds of family-to-family:
One who is a family-to-family in the heavens is born in two or three families in the heavens and realizes nirvÄá¹‡a, either in one heavenly realm or in two or three.
One who is a family-to-family among humans is born in two or three families among humans and realizes nirvÄá¹‡a, either in one continent or in two or three.

It is included in the seven births. The extreme of the seven is expressed by the extreme sound, because it shows the greatest number. For this reason, it is already shown that nirvÄá¹‡a obtained before the fulfillment of birth is also included in that.
One who is dullest in faculties experiences seven births. It is not definite that those of sharp faculties experience seven births.

Why is there no one who has eliminated five [afflictions] and is also called a family-to-family? Because when one has eliminated five [afflictions], one necessarily eliminates the sixth. One category of affliction cannot obstruct the attainment of the fruit, just as one who has one separation [from the peak of existence] has not yet transcended the realm.

One who has abandoned the first to the fifth category of the passions that are to be abandoned by cultivation is called one who is progressing toward the fruit of once-returning. If he abandons the sixth category, he becomes one who is a once-returner.

If he is reborn twice, he is reborn once in the heavens and once among humans.
The family-to-family among humans should be explained in the same way.
If this is not so, what is the difference between this and the family-to-family who is reborn twice?
The passions of craving, hatred, and delusion are only of the lowest grade, and therefore the one who is a once-returner is called one whose craving, hatred, and delusion are slight.
Having discussed the distinctions of the approachers and abiders in the fruit of once-returning, we shall next discuss the approachers and abiders in the fruit of non-returning.
A verse says:
One who has abandoned seven or eight categories is called one with one obstruction,
This is the third stage of the path of cultivation, and the ninth stage of the path of cultivation is the fruit of non-returning.
The treatise says:
The one who has attained the fruit of once-returning, if they further eliminate the remaining afflictions, if they possess three conditions, they are called one who has one separation.
First, by eliminating afflictions, they eliminate the seventh or eighth category of the afflictions to be eliminated through cultivation in the desire realm.
Second, by perfecting the faculties, they obtain the pure faculties that are able to eliminate those afflictions, both the uninterrupted path and the path of liberation.
Third, by receiving birth, they receive one more birth in the heavens or human realm of the desire realm.
If, among these three conditions, one is lacking, two are lacking, or all are lacking, they are not called one who has one separation, but they have perfected the pure faculties.
This is not mentioned in the verse, and should be further explained.
The causes for one birth should be explained according to the circumstances, just as in the case of the family families.
As for the meaning of separation, it is a synonym for gap. It means that in that state, there is a gap of one birth, and they have not yet attained nirvana.
Or, the meaning of the term antarÄ is that of being separated, because there is another birth that separates one from nirvÄá¹‡a.

How is this?
There is one separation because one remaining category of the passions of the realm of desire can obstruct and cause one to receive a birth in the realm of desire.

If one has not yet attained the fruit of the never-returner and eliminates this category, one will transcend the two fruits of retribution and the results of uniform outflow of actions and passions associated with the realm of desire.

Because they are extremely obstructive, one may receive birth again. When one eliminates six categories, one has not yet transcended that stage, and therefore there is no birth in the interim after eliminating five categories, because one is unable in this life to realize the fruit of the once-returner.
One who eliminates seven or eight categories of the passions of the realm of desire should be known as one who is intent on the fruit of the never-returner.

Is one who has previously eliminated three, four, seven, or eight categories of the passions of the realm of desire and enters into the vision of the truths subsequently called one who is reborn in only one more family and one who has one separation?
This is not yet called one who is reborn in only one more family and one who has one separation, because one has not yet acquired the pure faculties that cure those passions.
When one first attains the state of fruition, the path of fruition is present, but at that time one has not yet cultivated the superior path of fruition.

One must reach a later stage and give rise to the superior path of fruition in order to be called a once-returner or a non-returner, because the undefiled faculties that eliminate those [defilements] are attained at that time.

That is, one who has already attained the fruit of once-returning, when the nine grades of defilements of the desire realm are exhausted, abandons the name of once-returner and attains the fruit of non-returner, because one will definitely not return to receive birth in the desire realm.
This is also called the elimination of the five lower bonds. This is said in a hidden sense based on the elimination of the aggregates.
There is definitely no principle of the simultaneous elimination of the five bonds, because two or three have already been eliminated previously.
In the stage of non-returner, the various sutras establish distinctions through various approaches. Now we should discern their distinct characteristics.
The verse says:

The treatise says:

The one called parinirvÄá¹‡a in the middle refers to a certain person who has already attained the non-analytical cessation of the bonds of birth, but not so for the bonds of arising.

When they are oppressed by the conditions of oppression in the desire realm, they are able to encourage themselves to cultivate the superior practices that eliminate the remaining bonds. Before their practices are complete, they encounter the conditions of death and thus die. By the power of the bonds that arise, they receive a form-realm intermediate existence. As for those who attain parinirvÄá¹‡a upon rebirth, there is a type of person who, due to previously having fully created karma that accords with rebirth and having increased it, after death in the desire realm receives rebirth in the form realm. Based on the remaining support, it is said that they attain parinirvÄá¹‡a upon rebirth.
It is not that they immediately attain parinirvÄá¹‡a without remainder upon being reborn, because they lack mastery over abandoning life.

As for those who attain nirvana through exertion and those who attain nirvana without exertion, there is a type of person who, after being born, after a long time becomes an arhat. Those who attain nirvana without exertion are the opposite of this.

Or, those who are born in the form realm, after a long time, rely on the practice of suffering to liberate the remaining bonds, and are called those who attain nirvana through exertion, because they cultivate and enter nirvana relying on the path of applied practices.
Those who are the opposite of this are called those who attain nirvana without exertion.

Aren't the practices relied upon by those who attain nirvana in the intermediate state, those who attain nirvana upon rebirth, and those who attain nirvana through manifestation also like this? Therefore, the names of those who attain nirvana through exertion and those who attain nirvana without exertion should be established.
There is no such fault, because although the meaning is the same, each has a different stage.

That is to say, although those of the middle kind of parinirvÄá¹‡a, etc., also definitely rely on the practice of suffering and the practice of joy to liberate from bonds, each has a different stage, and this is called a special, uncommon difference.

This does not have such a different stage, and its difference is shown by the difference in the path. How can this be used as an example to make them the same? Therefore there is no fault in the explanation here.

As for the upper stream, it refers to a type of person whose upper stream increases, and who does not attain complete cessation in the first place of birth.

As for the complete death, it means that because of the abundance of craving for the form realm, they are born in all places. If this were not so, the abode of the great brahma would be a place of perverse views, and since he is the sole leader of the Brahmapurohita gods, there would be no saints who would be reborn there.

If this were not so, there would be no difference between the two types of those who attain nirvana from the highest existence. You must understand that this refers to the two types of those who attain nirvana from the highest existence, because they have the cause of the mixed cultivation of the trances.
Those who go to the peak of existence and attain nirvana go to the peak of existence and attain nirvana after being reborn in all the heavens of the form realm.

After death in the form realm, they are reborn in the three formless heavens in order, and finally they are reborn in the peak of existence and attain nirvana.

Of the two types of those who attain nirvana from the highest existence, the former are contemplatives and the latter are practitioners of tranquillization, because they delight in wisdom and delight in samÄdhi, respectively.
It is also reasonable to say that nonreturners who proceed to the upper levels attain nirvana in the lower levels.
However, it is said that they go to the heaven of the summit of existence and the peak of existence because this is the extreme limit.
There are no nonreturners who take a second birth in the place where they were born, because they seek to advance to a superior place of birth, not to an equal or inferior one.

Only those who die in the realm of desire and are born in the realm of form have a between existence that attains nirvana. Those who die in the realm of form and are born in the realm of form do not, because there is no calamity in the realm of form.
If there are other conditions that obstruct nirvana in the prior existence, there will be the same in the between existence, because the between existence is inferior to the prior existence.
Moreover, if there is a between existence, it must belong to the upper stream.

There would be no difference between attaining nirvana in the middle and the upper stream, because there is no reason to say that only those who die in the realm of desire and experience a between existence in the realm of form attain nirvana in the middle, and not those who die in the realm of form.
Why is it that learners who have not yet eliminated desire are not reborn in the intermediate state?
Because the body of the intermediate state in the desire realm is weak and lacks the ability to perform many tasks.

While dwelling in the original state, it is difficult to transcend the dharmas of the desire realm, let alone in the intermediate state to transcend the desire realm and attain the fruit of arhatship.
Many tasks refer to transcending the three realms, permanently eliminating the two kinds of afflictions, and attaining the second and third fruits of the Å›ramaá¹‡a.
While dwelling in the intermediate state, one does not have this ability.
Moreover, one has not yet repeatedly cultivated the nine grades of afflictions and their antidotes.

Also, the fruits of non-returner and so forth are not attained by the body of the intermediate state, because they are attained through eliminating the dominant afflictions, and it is extremely difficult to be free from the defilements of the three realms.

There is no desire in the intermediate state that can attain nirvana. The intermediate state of the form realm is different from this in all respects, and therefore there are those who attain nirvana in the intermediate state.
Moreover, those who attain nirvana in this realm only give rise to the noble path that exists in this realm.

Those who attain nirvana in the intermediate state in the first meditative absorption only manifest the noble path of the fundamental meditative absorption of their own stage, not the preliminary or intermediate stages, because it is difficult to manifest them. In the intermediate state, the body is extremely weak, and only those that are easy to manifest can be manifested.
These five are called those who proceed to the form realm.

Those who proceed to the formless realm are of four types, namely those who, in the desire realm, are free from craving for the form realm and, upon the termination of this life, are born in the formless realm. The differences among them are only of four kinds, due to the differences of birth, etc.
Together with the previous five, they make six non-returners.
There are also those who do not proceed to the form or formless realms but who are able to attain nirvana right here, called those who attain nirvana upon manifesting.
Together with the previous six, they make seven.
Or, in total, nine types of non-returners should be established, namely those who attain nirvana upon manifesting, which are divided into two types:
one who is able to skillfully discern the noble purport in a previous stage and one who is able to skillfully discern it only at the time of death.
Within the upper stream, there are also two types:
one who practices in the form realm and one who practices in the formless realm.
Together with the previous four, there are eight, which become nine when added to the one who transforms and is born.

As for the one who transforms and is born, it refers to one who has already attained the fruit of stream-entry or once-returner in a previous life, but only attains the fruit of non-returner in this life.
The previous term one who attains parinirvÄá¹‡a in the present life only refers to the present life.

The one who attains parinirvÄá¹‡a in the intermediate state, the one who attains parinirvÄá¹‡a upon rebirth, and the one who does not return, due to differences in faculties, are divided into nine types according to their respective abilities, or among the five non-returners who practice in the form realm.
There is another method of division into nine types.
The verse states:
There are nine who practice in the form realm, each divided into three,
Due to differences in karma, afflictions, and faculties, they become three groups of nine.
The treatise states:
The five types of non-returners who practice in the form realm are generally established as three, each divided into three types, thus becoming nine types.
What are the three?
Because there are differences in the middle, rebirth, and upper stream.
How are these three each divided into three?

The parinirvÄá¹‡a in the intermediate state is divided into three because there are differences in the time of arising, the distance to the place of rebirth, and the proximity to the place of rebirth.
The parinirvÄá¹‡a at birth is divided into three because there are differences in the time of birth, the time of practice, and the time of no practice.
All of these attain parinirvÄá¹‡a after birth, and therefore they should all be called parinirvÄá¹‡a at birth.

In the upward stream, it is divided into three because there are differences in the complete transcendence, the partial transcendence, and the complete death.ğŸ”½However, all three are divided into nine types because they attain parinirvÄá¹‡a quickly, not quickly, and after a long time.

These three types of non-returners, due to differences in karma, afflictions, and faculties, have differences in being quick, not quick, and after a long time. First, they are generally divided into three.

Because of the difference in the karma that was previously accumulated that is conducive to rebirth, according to the superior, middling, and inferior grades, because of the difference in the actual dharmas of the passions that are superior, middling, and inferior, and because of the difference in the superior, middling, and inferior faculties.
Each of these three is divided according to its proper case.
It is also because of the difference in karma, passions, and faculties that each is divided into three, making nine kinds.
That is, the first two and the first three are divided into three kinds according to the difference in passions and faculties, and not because of the difference in karma.
The last three are also divided into three kinds because of the difference in karma that is conducive to rebirth in a later life.
Therefore it is said that the nonreturners who proceed to the form realm are distinguished as three and nine kinds because of the difference in karma, passions, and faculties.
If this is so, why does the Buddha in the scriptures speak only of the existence of seven destinies of good persons?
A verse says:
The seven destinies of good persons are established because there is no distinction in the upper stream.
Because of good and evil conduct and nonconduct, there is going but no returning.
The treatise says:
Each of the middle two has three, and the upper stream is one. The sutra establishes seven destinies of good persons based on this.
Why are the first two each divided into three, and the third upper stream only established as one?
Because of superior practice, it is called the upper stream. For this reason, it is the same and only established as one.
Although the first two are also the same in meaning, they are difficult to understand in their specific characteristics. In order to make them easier to understand, they are each divided into three.
The upper stream has three different characteristics that are easy to understand, so there is no need to establish them separately.
Moreover, the first two have only the difficulty of showing the place, so they are each divided into three.
The third upper stream has many different meanings, which are difficult to show, so it is generally established as one.
That is, the first type of parinirvÄá¹‡a only occurs in the future, and is divided into three types due to differences in faculties and afflictions.
The second type of parinirvÄá¹‡a only occurs in the present, and is also divided into three types due to differences in faculties and afflictions.
The upper stream has both the future and the present.
Those who are about to be born in the upper two destinies are also of two kinds, namely, those who have cultivated the meditations with and without distinction.
Those who have already been born in the upper two destinies are also divided in the same way.

Moreover, among these two upper destinies, if one has not cultivated the meditations with distinction, one may be born in the two realms. If one has cultivated the meditations with distinction, one is only born in one realm.
Those who are born in one realm are further divided into three, because of the differences of complete transcendence, half transcendence, and complete submersion.

Within half transcendence, there are many distinctions. The characteristics of the upper destinies are numerous and extensive. If each is explained individually, it is difficult to fully understand. Therefore, based on the meaning of equality, the upper destinies are generally established.
The distinctions in the states of the middle and the born are few in meaning and easy to understand, so they are divided into six.
Although each of them also has the meaning of equality, they are equal to the third.
Although there are different meanings in the upper destinies, they are equal to the first two.
In order to illustrate the characteristics, only seven are established.
Only those who have already severed attachment to desire, anger, etc., are not good people's dharmas and are not learners.
Because the fruit of the great man is extremely close to it, the scripture only says that it is called the destination of the good man.
It is not that the stream-enterer and once-returner cannot be said to be the destination of the good man at all, because the Buddha also calls them good men.
As a scripture says:
What is a good man?

It means one who has attained the correct view of the learner, up to one who has attained the correct concentration of the learner. Going upward is called the destination, which means the destination of the upper fruit and the destination of the upper birth.
Therefore, only seven are mentioned.
Or only these seven are able to practice good and not practice evil, while the others are not.
Also, only these seven are reborn in the upper realms and do not return again, while the others are not like this.
Therefore, only these are established as the destination of the good man.
Do those who have already experienced birth in the holy stage also have these distinctions?
No, it is not so.
How is it?
The verse says:
The scriptures say that the noble ones born in the desire realm do not go to be born in other realms,
Those who are born above do not sharpen their faculties or retrogress.
The treatise says:

Those in the holy position who have experienced birth in the desire realm will definitely not be reborn in the form or formless realms, because they have already realized the fruit of non-returning and will definitely attain parinirvÄá¹‡a in their present body.
If a holy one has experienced birth in the form realm, there is the meaning of being reborn above in the formless realm.
However, Indra Åšakra said:
I have heard of a heaven called Akaniá¹£á¹­ha. After I fall, I will be reborn there.
This is because he did not understand the characteristics of the antidotes.

Those who have already experienced birth in the desire realm, and those holy ones who have been reborn above in other realms, definitely do not sharpen their faculties or retrogress, because they have already experienced birth and accumulated the holy path in their own continuum, which is extremely firm, and because they have attained a superior physical basis.

It was previously said that the upper stream, by cultivating the meditations with mixed meditation as its cause, is able to go to the Akaniá¹£á¹­ha Heaven. What kind of meditation should one first mix and cultivate?
By what stage is it known that mixed cultivation is accomplished?
For what reason do they cultivate the formless concentrations in combination?
Verse:
First, mixed cultivation of the fourth, accomplished by one thought of mixed cultivation,
For the sake of rebirth, present bliss, and preventing the retrogression of afflictions.
Discussion:

Those who wish to cultivate the four formless concentrations in combination must first cultivate the fourth concentration in combination, because that concentration is the most capable, and among the blissful practices, it is the most excellent.
Who can cultivate the concentrations in combination?
Only the noble ones, both learners and post-learners. In the learner stage, it is only the faith-liberated and view-attainer.

In the post-learner stage, it is both the timely and untimely. They must first cultivate the combined concentrations in the three continents. Even if they retrogress and are reborn in the form realm, they can still cultivate the combined concentrations. After retrogressing, they sharpen their faculties and become the view-attainer type.

From the desire realm, they pass away and are reborn in the form realm. Riding on the previous [practice], they are again able to cultivate the combined concentrations. Therefore, the six types of lineages all have the upward stream.
When cultivating the combined [practice], what expedient means do they employ?

One must first enter the fourth meditative absorption, with many moments of the uncontaminated state appearing in succession. From this, one induces many moments of the contaminated state. Later, many moments of the uncontaminated state appear again. In this way, the cycle continues, with each subsequent moment gradually decreasing, until finally there are two moments of the uncontaminated state, which then induce two moments of the contaminated state to appear. Immediately after this, two moments of the uncontaminated state are produced again, called the completion of the preparatory practice of the meditation that combines the two.

From this point on, without the need for effort, one spontaneously induces only one moment of the contaminated state to appear from a single moment of the uncontaminated state, which is immediately followed by the production of one moment of the uncontaminated state.

The contaminated state in the middle moment is mixed with the uncontaminated states of the preceding and following moments, and for this reason it is called the fundamental perfection of the meditation that combines the two.
Having thus combined the fourth meditative absorption, one is able to combine the lower three meditative absorptions as appropriate by the power of this practice.
The meditation that combines the two has the five aggregates as its essence.
However, in this case, all worldly cognition is cultivated by the four dharmas, four types, and eight cognitions.
There are three general conditions for cultivating the formless concentrations:
First, for the sake of rebirth; second, for the sake of present happiness; third, for the sake of preventing the retrogression of afflictions.
Among the non-returners, if of the type of one attaining by insight, it is for the first two conditions; if of the type of one attaining by faith, it is for all three conditions.

Among the arhats, those liberated regardless of occasion are only for present happiness; those liberated upon occasion are for the latter two conditions. If one cultivates the formless concentrations, it is for rebirth in the five pure abodes.
Why are there only five pure abodes?
The verse states:
Due to the five categories of mixed cultivation, there are five pure abodes.
The treatise states:
Because there are five categories of mixed cultivation of the fourth concentration, there are only five pure abodes.
What are the five categories?
They are distinguished as lower, middle, upper, upper-superior, and upper-extreme categories.
In this case, the first stage is completed by the manifestation of three minds, that is, the first pure mind, next the contaminated mind, and next the pure mind.
The second middling stage is completed only after the manifestation of six minds, that is, two contaminated minds and four pure minds that are mixed with each other.
In this way, the remaining stages are completed by the manifestation of nine, twelve, and fifteen minds, respectively, in the proper order.
These five grades of mixed cultivation are causes that respectively attract the five fruits of the pure abodes.
These fifteen contaminated and uncontaminated minds are all obtained now for the first time.
Other masters say that
the first five uncontaminated minds are obtained for the first time, and the remaining ten minds are all minds that have been obtained previously.

When the first five are manifested, they are cultivated in the future, and therefore one does not leave samÄdhi. In the completion of mixed cultivation, it is necessary to manifest them many times in order to perfect them.
Other masters say:

The five beginning with faith are dominant conditions for the five pure residences. The attainment of the five pure residences is due to the power of mixed cultivation, and also due to the power of karma assisting each other.
However, only impure dharmas can attract the retribution of those pure residences, not pure dharmas, because they abandon existence.
The scriptures say that nonreturners are called body witnesses.
On the basis of what superior qualities is this name established?
The verse says:
Nonreturners who attain the concentration of cessation are called body witnesses.
The treatise says:
Those who attain the concentration of cessation are called those who attain the concentration of cessation.

If nonreturners have the attainment of the concentration of cessation in their bodies, they are called body witnesses. This means that nonreturners are called body witnesses because they realize a dharma similar to nirvana through the body.
How can they be said to be only body witnesses?
Because they are without mind.
Because they are born in dependence on the body, because the attainment born with the body has powerful force, even when they have already extinguished it, they are still said to attain it.
Why did the Buddha say that those still learning are fields of merit, but those who have realized the body-witness and nonreturners are not included in that number?
The World-Honored One told AnÄthapiá¹‡á¸ada:
Elder, you should know that there are two kinds of fields of merit:
those still learning and those beyond learning.
Those still learning are eighteen, while those beyond learning are only nine.
What are the eighteen still learning?

They are those striving for the fruit of stream-entry, those striving for the fruit of once-returning, those striving for the fruit of nonreturning, those striving for the fruit of arhatship, those following faith and those following the Dharma, those with faith and those with insight, those returning once to their families, those returning once to their families, those who pass away in the intermediate state, those who pass away with practice, those who pass away without practice, and those who go upstream. These are called the eighteen.
What are the nine kinds beyond learning?

They are those who regress, those who contemplate, those who guard, those who abide securely, those who can penetrate, those who are unshakable, those who do not regress, those liberated by wisdom, and those liberated by both. These are called the nine.

Although it should be explained, it is not explained because the Buddha sees that those still learning and those beyond learning, due to the differences in what is eliminated and faculties, are able to give rise to superior fruits and are called fields of merit.

However, the samÄdhi of cessation obtained by those who return is impure, and therefore it cannot be said that it is pure because it is liberated by its very nature. The body on which it is based still has the passions that have not been eternally extinguished, and therefore it cannot be said that it is pure because the series is liberated. Therefore it is not a question of establishing the field of merit of those in training.

The impure qualities of the stage of post-learning, even though they are not included in that which is liberated by its very nature, are called pure because the series is liberated. Consequently, they are also able to produce superior fruits.
Therefore, in terms of the differences in samÄdhi and faculties, the nine fruits of the religious life are all called the field of merit.
The coarse differences of those who return for one more rebirth have already been discussed. If we analyze them in detail, there are many thousands of types.
Here we have discussed them in terms of five types who go to the form realm, distinguishing them in terms of five topics such as the stages.
That is, they are distinguished in terms of the stages and are twenty in number, because there are five types in each of the four trance stages.
They are distinguished in terms of the five lineages and are thirty in number, because there are five types in each of the six lineages.
If we consider the number of nonreturners according to the place of birth, there are eighty, because there are five kinds in each of the sixteen places.

If we consider the number of nonreturners according to their spiritual genes and faculties, there are ninety, because there are differences in the spiritual genes of those who regress, of those of average faculties, and of those of superior faculties, and the number is made up of fifteen. The same is true of the spiritual genes of those who do not regress.
If we consider the number of nonreturners according to their spiritual genes and stages, there are one hundred twenty, because there are thirty in each of the four stages.
If we consider the number of nonreturners according to their spiritual genes, stages, and faculties, there are three hundred sixty, because there are ninety in each of the four stages.

If we consider the number of nonreturners according to their spiritual genes, places of birth, and stages, there are four hundred eighty, because there are thirty in each of the sixteen places.ğŸ”½If we consider the number of nonreturners according to their spiritual genes, places of birth, and faculties, there are one thousand four hundred forty, because there are ninety in each of the sixteen places.

If we consider the number of nonreturners according to their degrees of freedom from passion, places of birth, spiritual genes, and faculties, the total number of different nonreturners is twelve thousand nine hundred sixty, because there are nine degrees of freedom from passion, and we multiply the previous number of one thousand four hundred forty by nine.
